0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Condyloma acuminatum, External: apply a 0.5 cm strand of ointment topically 3 times daily to each external genital and perianal warts; continue treatment until complete clearance of warts, but no longer than 16 weeks

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients; not recommended for treatment of urethral, intravaginal, cervical, rectal, or intra-anal human papilloma viral disease

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: history of sensitivity reactions to any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• avoid use on open wounds
  • may weaken condoms and vaginal diaphragms; use in combination not recommended
  • not recommended for treatment of urethral, intra-vaginal, cervical, rectal, or intra-anal human papilloma viral disease

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Burning sensation (67%), Edema (45%), Erythema (70%), Induration of skin (35%), Pruritus (69%), Rash, Vesicular (20%), Superficial ulcer of skin (49%)
  • Other:Pain (56%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The exact mechanism of action against external genital or perianal warts is unknown. In vitro, sinecatechins have antioxidant activity; however, the clinical significance of this function in not known it is not known.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • wash hand well before and after application
  • washing treated area prior to next application is not necessary
  • use fingers to apply ointment to each wart and ensure complete coverage; leave a thin lay or ointment on the warts
  • ointment may stain clothing or bedding

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• clinical response on the number and area of involvement with genital and/or perianal warts
  • signs of excessive or worsening application site reactions (local pain, erythema, vesicles, skin erosion/ulceration, induration)
  • open sores, signs or symptoms of genital herpes simplex, and superinfection of warts and ulcers

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that drug may weaken condoms or vaginal diaphragms. Recommend additional form of birth control.
  • Ointment may stain bedding or clothing.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of excessive or worsening application site reactions (local pain, erythema, vesicles, skin erosion/ulceration induration).
  • Instruct patient to avoid use on open wounds.
